ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Thermally stimulated terahertz radiation of plasmon–phonon polaritons in GaAs

Affiliation.OrgName: Center for Physical Sciences and Technology

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The thermally stimulated excitation of radiative modes of surface plasmon–phonon polaritons in GaAs followed by the high-power terahertz (THz) radiation selective emission is studied and experimentally observed. The selective high-power THz radiation emitters in the 7–8 and 10–15 THz frequency ranges based on the heated highly doped (n>5⋅1017 cm−3) GaAs plates are proposed.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Investigations of terahertz (THz) radiation interaction with materials open the way for many kinds of spectroscopic applications, covering semiconductor characterization, bio-medical imaging, security screening, space research, etc. [1–6]. However, the problem of the unavailable intense THz emission source prevents the rapid development of the above mentioned applications.

The studies of semiconductors as THz emitters have gained much attention either in bulk form or as thin film-based devices. The THz emission from femtosecond-laser-irradiated GaAs thin films and bulk crystals are widely used as THz emitters in the THz Time Domain Spectroscopy [7–15]. The thermally stimulated electromagnetic fields of solids are considered in [16–19].
Recently, the continuous wave THz radiation caused by surface plasmon–phonon oscillations in highly doped GaAs in the 5–15 THz frequency range has been revealed [4].

In this paper, the thermally excited radiative modes of surface plasmon–phonon oscillations in highly doped GaAs plate are studied, and possibilities for their application as a selective thermal THz source are considered.

Section1.Heading: Coupled plasmon–phonon oscillations in GaAs
Section1.Para:

The experimentally observed reflection minima ω

In highly doped GaAs (i.e., ω
p >ω

S2 in the wide THz area except the narrow area at TO phonon frequency (ω≤ω
T ), where ε(ω
T )>0. The condition ε(ω)<0 means that electromagnetic radiation can not propagate in bulk GaAs. Indeed, the radiation transmission through the GaAs layer is not observed experimentally in a wide range of frequencies including the minimal reflection frequencies ω
S1 and ω
S2. The radiation transmission is absent in spite of the fact that a large part of the incident radiation is not reflected from the GaAs surface and is penetrated into the GaAs plate. Therefore, we have assumed that the penetrated (not reflected) part of the incident light is absorbed in a thin surface layer of the GaAs plate. We suppose that the interaction of the incident light with the coupled mode of the surface GaAs/air plasmon–phonon oscillations is responsible for the absorption. The radiation absorption at ε(ω)<0 arises due to interaction with the surface plasmon–phonon polaritons at frequencies ω
S1 and ω
S2.
The experimentally observed THz radiation reflection minima take place at ε(ω)<0 in a range where the surface plasmon–phonons exist.

It is worth to note that in a case of ε(ω)=0, the oscillations with the frequency of the coupled plasmon–LO phonons take place in bulk GaAs [10]. However, as it has shown in [10, 11, 13], at ε=0, the reflected radiation electromagnetic field is produced without an incident one. This means that a self-sustaining resonant oscillation occurs in the bulk with the plasmon–LO phonon frequencies. It has been shown in [11] that at ε=−1, the self-sustaining oscillations can be excited near the reflecting interface without any incident power.

Therefore, at ε(ω)≤0, the THz radiation created in highly doped GaAs can “leave” the crystal at selective frequencies of surface plasmon–phonons and bulk plasmon–LO phonons, and be recorded as thermal emission of a “nonblack body-type.” The customary “black body-type” emission takes place at ω=ω
T and at ω>ω
S2, where ε(ω)>0.
Consequently, the heating of GaAs is leaded by two types of radiation emission: the plasmon–phonon radiation resonance emission at ε(ω)≤0 and the Planck “black body-type” emission at ε(ω)>0.

Section1.Heading: Thermally stimulated THz reflectivity and emissivity of plasmon–phonon polaritons in GaAs
Section1.Para: In our experiments, we used the method of thermally stimulated emission of vibrational state in single crystals and interfaces [14, 17].

The high conductivity (n>3⋅1017 cm−3) GaAs polished plates with an area of 1.6 cm2 and thickness of 350 μm were heated by electric current. The reflection and emission spectra of the heated GaAs plate were measured by IR spectrometer-transformer Nicolet 8700 (Thermo Scientific).

The magnitude of the measured thermally excited signal is determined by the difference of temperatures of the GaAs sample, T, and detector, T 0. In our experiments, the temperature of the heated GaAs sample achieved 260 °C and temperature of the detector in all experiments was 20 °C.

Figure 3 demonstrates the temperature-dependent THz reflection spectra of the heated GaAs plate.
Fig. 3
Reflection spectra from the highly doped (n
p =4⋅1017 cm−3) GaAs plate at different temperatures. The maximal values of thermally stimulated THz radiation absorption are labeled by I max=I absmax/I
K

The experimentally measured reflection coefficient R(T) decreases with increasing temperature T of GaAs sample in a wide range of the measured spectra of 200–400 cm−1. It should be noted that a strong decrease (three times at T=260 °C) of reflectivity with an increase of temperature is observed.

We assume that the thermally stimulated THz radiation absorption I abs(T) by surface plasmon–phonon polaritons is responsible for the temperature-dependent behavior of reflectivity spectra: 3
$$ I_{\mathrm{abs}}(T) = \bigl( R(T_{0}) - R(T) \bigr)I_{K}, $$ where I
K is the intensity of the incident (black body) radiation in the measuring channel of IR spectrometer and R(T 0) is the reflectivity at T 0=20 °C. Note that the I abs(T) spectra are modulated by sharp spikes caused by the interaction of incident radiation I
K with water vapors in the air.

Taken into account the fast increase of I
K ∼ω 2, the data of Fig. 3 shows that the maximum I abs(T) takes place at ω
S1=240 and ω
S2=370 cm−1. That coincides with the surface plasmon–phonon frequencies for the GaAs sample (see Fig. 2). However, the I abs≈0, at frequencies ω=270 and ω>450 cm−1, where ε(ω)>0.

The thermally stimulated THz absorption I abs(T) at the resonance frequency increases with temperature T–T 0, whereas I abs(T) is absent at the TO phonon frequency (ω=ω
T ) and at ω>450 cm−1, where ε(ω)>0.

Therefore, the strong effect of the selective incident radiation absorption at the frequencies of coupled surface plasmon–phonon oscillations is detected in the conductive GaAs plate. Two absorption maxima at ω
S1 (narrow peak) and ω
S2 are observed. The thermal excitation of surface plasmon–phonon oscillations followed by the increase of radiation absorption and the decrease of reflection is determined.

We assume that the giant increase in the density of states of surface plasmon–phonon waves of the thermally stimulated field in the thin (<10−2 μm) surface region [16–19] can be responsible for the resonance enhancement of absorption at ω
S1 and ω
S2.

Figure 4 demonstrates the thermally exited THz emission I em(T) spectra of the highly doped GaAs sample in a range of 200–600 cm−1 at different temperatures.
Fig. 4
Thermally stimulated THz emission I em spectra of the heated highly doped GaAs plate (n
p =6⋅1017 cm−3) at different temperatures

One can see that the thermally stimulated radiation intensity spectrum is characterized by two maxima at frequencies labeled as ω rad1=250 and ω rad2=430 cm−1. These frequencies are near to the coupled plasmon–LO phonon and surface plasmon–phonon resonance frequencies ω
S1=256 and ω
S2=440 cm−1 for this GaAs sample (n
p =6⋅1017 cm−3) (see Fig. 2). Therefore, the thermal excitation of surface plasmon–phonon oscillations is responsible for the observed thermally stimulated THz emission.

At ω>500 cm−1, the dielectric function of the GaAs sample becomes positive. This means that the emitted radiation does not belong to the surface plasmon–phonon polariton emission, and it is determined by thermally enhanced black body radiation.

According to the Kirchhoff law, the thermally excited radiation emission is given by 4
$$ I_{\mathrm{em}}(\omega,T) = \bigl[ 1 - R(\omega,T) \bigr]I_{\mathrm{bb}}( \omega,T), $$ where R(ω,T) is the reflection coefficient and I bb(ω,T) is the equilibrium intensity of emission, which is independent on a material of the black body cavity.

The thermally excited surface plasmon–phonon polaritons induce the strong decrease of the reflection coefficient R(ω,T), and consequently, increase the intensity of thermally stimulated THz emission. We assume that the observed emission resonance maxima correspond to the reflection coefficient resonance minima ω
S1 and ω
S2.
Because of a strong decrease of the reflection coefficient R(ω,T) with temperature, the emitted light intensity I em(ω,T) can achieve the value close to the I bb(ω,T).

The THz emission power was measured by pyroelectric power meter Vector H410 (Scientech, Inc.) The measured power density at T=160 °C in a bandwidth of 10–15 THz (limited by THz band pass filter) was 13.2 mW cm−2. That is comparable with the black body emission value 17 mW cm−2 for the heated GaAs calculated in the same bandwidth.
Consequently, the heated GaAs plate can be used as a high-power continuous wave radiation source in selected 7–8 and 10–15 THz frequency ranges.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
At the first time, the thermally stimulated continuous wave THz radiation from the highly doped GaAs (n
p >5⋅1017 cm−3) is experimentally observed. It is found that thermal excitation of the coupled free electron plasma and interface (GaAs/air) optical phonon oscillations are responsible for the strong decrease of the reflectivity and increase of emission intensity in the 7–8 and 10–15 THz ranges.
The heated highly doped GaAs plate can be used as the selective high intensity (>10 mW cm−2) continuous wave THz radiation emitter.
